title: 19th Century Philippines
subtitle: Explore the historical context of the Philippines during the 19th century: Spanish Colonial System, Social Classes, Church Power, Education System, and Economic Conditions.

special_features.title: Colonial Policies:
items: Polo y servicio (forced labor for 40 days)
Tribute system requiring payment in rice or money
Bandala system (forced sale of products to government)
Encomienda system (land grants with native labor)
Galleon trade monopoly connecting Manila to Acapulco

issues.title: Systematic Corruption:
issues.description: Government positions were often sold or given as rewards for loyalty. Officials were expected to recoup their investments through various means, leading to widespread exploitation of the native population.

issues.title: Indulto de Comercio:
issues.description: Provincial governors engaged in illegal trade monopolies, forcing natives to sell products at below-market prices and buy goods at inflated costs.

issues.title: Arbitrary Justice:
issues.description: Spanish officials often acted as judge, jury, and executioner. Justice was frequently bought and sold, with little recourse for ordinary Filipinos.

powers.description: Friars often wielded more practical power than civil officials in rural areas. They influenced appointments of local officials and could effectively veto government policies they opposed.
Handled marriages, inheritance disputes, and moral issues. Their decisions were often final and could not be appealed to civil courts.
Controlled what books could be read, what ideas could be taught, and what newspapers could be published. Maintained intellectual control over the population.

conflicts.title: Secularization Movement:
conflicts.description: Growing demand to replace Spanish friars with Filipino secular priests. Led to tensions between Spanish religious orders and Filipino clergy who felt discriminated against.

conflicts.title: Gomburza Martyrdom:
conflicts.description: Execution of Filipino priests Gomez, Burgos, and Zamora in 1872 on charges of sedition. This event galvanized Filipino nationalism and anti-friar sentiment.

conflicts.title: Nationalist Criticism:
conflicts.description: Writers like Rizal in his novels exposed friar abuses, corruption, and hypocrisy. This literary campaign significantly damaged church prestige and authority.

problems.description: Despite agricultural abundance, most Filipino farmers lived in poverty due to exploitative land tenure systems, heavy taxation, and forced labor requirements.
Spanish colonial policy discouraged manufacturing in the Philippines to maintain dependence on Spanish goods, limiting economic diversification and growth.
Economic benefits of trade growth concentrated among Spanish colonists, church, and small Filipino elite, while majority remained impoverished.
Bandala system and focus on export crops over food production led to periodic food shortages and famines, especially during bad harvests.
